official-title.#text:
Recognizing the 100th Anniversary of the
		  establishment of the Department of Labor.

sponsor.#tail:
submitted the following resolution; which was referred to
			 the

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Education and the
			 Workforce

text.#text: That the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: ; and

text.#text:
recognizes the
			 100th anniversary of the establishment of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
to
			 improve the lives of working people.

text.#text:
congratulates and
			 commends all those who have served as employees of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
has fostered, promoted, and developed the welfare of wage earners, job seekers,
			 and retirees of the Nation;

text.#text: Whereas, for the past 100 years, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
has continually sought to
			 make the American workplace safer, healthier, and fairer for everyone;

text.#text: Whereas the

Whereas working families across the Nation and around the
			 world have benefitted from the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
has historically
			 championed many of the cherished characteristics of work life in the United
			 States, including the 40-hour work week, weekends, overtime pay, the right to
			 collectively bargain, unemployment insurance, and the prohibition of child
			 labor;

text.#text: Whereas the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
has evolved to meet the
			 changing needs of the workforce by partnering with employers, community
			 organizations and institutions of higher learning to improve job training,
			 provide lifelong learning opportunities, and advance efforts for profitable
			 employment;

text.#text: Whereas the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the

text.#text: Whereas, since the passage of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
has served the
			 Nation for nearly 130 years, predating the

, by measuring and
			 analyzing statistical data in order to provide policymakers, economists,
			 investors, and the public with open, accurate information about the workforce
			 and economy;

text.#text: Whereas the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and the

text.#text:
Whereas, after decades of serious injury or loss of life
			 as a result of unsafe working conditions, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: in Washington, DC, in 1919, the

has engaged with the international community to promote the values of
			 fairness, justice, and respect for human dignity around the world, continuing
			 its role as a vital partner in the Nation’s efforts to combat human trafficking
			 and child labor through extensive research and reporting and technical
			 cooperation projects;

text.#text: Whereas, after hosting the first meeting of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: which, in part, created the
, the

has administered the education and vocational training program with a mission
			 to attract eligible young people, teach them the skills they need to become
			 employable and independent, and place them in meaningful jobs or further their
			 education;

text.#text: Whereas, since President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
provides critical protection for the pension, health, and other
			 employee benefits promised to workers and their families, through its

(ERISA); the

text.#text: Whereas the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
continues to strive to
			 achieve the aims of the Civil Rights era by protecting access to economic
			 opportunity for all Americans and eradicating discrimination in the
			 workplace;

text.#text: Whereas the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
has promoted and defended
			 gender equality in the workplace, and since 1919, the

has developed standards and polices to ensure fair treatment of women in
			 the workplace;

text.#text: Whereas the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
was established by President Johnson, with the aim of
			 holding Federal contractors to a higher obligation for affirmative action by
			 prohibiting such contractors and subcontractors from making employment
			 decisions that discriminate based on race, sex, color, religion, or national
			 origin;
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Office of Federal Contract
			 Compliance Programs
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs

text.#text: Whereas, in 1965, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the

has dramatically
			 expanded the idea of inclusion in the American workforce by prohibiting
			 discriminatory practices on the basis of a disability and promoting the concept
			 of reasonable accommodation;

text.#text: Whereas, after passage of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: created the

, which today provides wage
			 replacement benefits, medical treatment, vocational rehabilitation, and other
			 benefits for disabled Federal Government workers, longshore workers, coal mine
			 workers, energy workers, and overseas contractors, along with eligible
			 dependents and survivors;

text.#text: Whereas, in 1916, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the

Migrant and

has played an evolving role in
